case_name: State of Mysore v. the respondent

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1010 of 1965 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1010 of 1965. . Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 11, 1963 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 1601 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 11, 1963 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 1601 of 1962. V. Gupte, Solicitor-General, R. Ganapathy Iyer and R. Dhebar, for the appellant.

facts.text: V. Gupte, Solicitor-General, R. Ganapathy Iyer and R. Dhebar appeared for the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: V. Gupte, Solicitor-General, R. Ganapathy Iyer and R. Dhebar, for the appellant. R. Ethiarajulu Naidu, K. Rajendra Chaudhuri and K. R. Chaudhuri, for the respondent.

facts.text: R. Ethiarajulu Naidu, K. Rajendra Chaudhuri and K. R. Chaudhuri appeared for the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: R. Ethiarajulu Naidu, K. Rajendra Chaudhuri and K. R. Chaudhuri, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J.

facts.text: By S. 37 of the Mysore Forest Act 11 of 1900 the State Government is authorized to make rules to regulate the transit of forest produce.

anchor.surface_text: By S. 37 of the Mysore Forest Act 11 of 1900 the State Government is authorized to make rules to regulate the transit of . . . forest produce.

facts.text: State Government of Mysore framed rules under S. 37 to regulate transit of timber, firewood, charcoal and bamboos from all lands.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the powers conferred by S. 37 the State Government of Mysore has framed rules to regulate the transit of timber, firewood, charcoal and bamboos from all lands.

facts.text: Rule 2 framed on October 13, 1952 provided that no person shall import, export or move forest produce within Scheduled area without permit prescribed in r. 3.

anchor.surface_text: By r. 2 framed on October 13, 1952 it was provided that no person shall import forest produce into, export forest produce from, or move forest produce within, any of the areas specified in Sch. A hereinafter referred to as the Scheduled area , unless such forest produce is accompanied by a permit prescribed in r. 3.

facts.text: On April 15, 1959 the State of Mysore issued a notification adding a proviso to r. 2 prohibiting transport of forest produce between sun-set and sun-rise in Schedule A areas.

anchor.surface_text: On April 15, 1959 the State of Mysore issued a notification adding a proviso to r. 2 which read as follows Provided that no such permit shall authorise any person to transport forest produce between sun-set and sun-rise in any of the areas specified in Schedule A.

facts.text: By notification dated September 14, 1960, the State Government introduced the second proviso to r. 2 allowing timber merchants to transport timber up to 10 P.M. upon paying Rs. 1,000 cash deposit as security.

anchor.surface_text: By another notification dated September 14, 1960, the State Government introduced the second proviso to r. 2 which read Provided further that permission may be granted to timber merchants on their requisition to transport timber up to 10 P.M. (22 hrs.) under the following conditions - the party who wishes to avail of the concessions should pay a cash deposit of Rs. 1,000 as security for due compliance with the timber transit rules as in force that the deposit may be forfeited to Government for breach of any of the conditions of the Timber Transit Rules.

facts.text: The respondent is a dealer in timber.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent who is a dealer in timber filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution

facts.text: Respondent filed a writ petition under Art. 226 to quash the two provisos to r. 2.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent who is a dealer in timber filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution for an order quashing the two provisos to r. 2, on the grounds inter alia that the two provisos were beyond the rule-making authority conferred upon the State Government by s. 37 of the Mysore Forest Act 11 of 1900,

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 1601 of 1962 was filed by respondent.

anchor.surface_text: of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 1601 of 1962. V. Gupte, Solicitor-General, R. Ganapathy Iyer and R. Dhebar, for the appellant. R. Ethiarajulu Naidu, K. Rajendra Chaudhuri and K. R. Chaudhuri, for the respondent.

facts.text: Mysore High Court held that the two provisos to r. 2 were beyond powers under s. 37, prohibitory not regulatory.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Mysore held that by the provisos inserted in r. 2 the State Government had while seeking to regulate the transport of timber stopped transport altogether, and in doing so the State Government acted in excess of the powers conferred upon it by s. 37 of the Act.

facts.text: High Court held provisos not saved by Art. 305, violative of Art. 301.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also held that the two provisos were not saved by Art 305 of the Constitution and since the function of the two provisos was not regulatory but prohibitory, they were violative of Art. 301 of the Constitution and must be struck down as unconstitutional.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to State of Mysore to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: With special leave granted by this Court, the State of Mysore has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Mysore Forest Act 11 of 1900 was enacted.

anchor.surface_text: By S. 37 of the Mysore Forest Act 11 of 1900 the State Government is authorized

facts.text: Section 37(1) vests control of forest produce in transit and rivers for floating timber in State Government, which may make rules to regulate transit.

anchor.surface_text: Section 37 (1) of the Mysore Forest Act 11 of 1900 provides The control of all rivers and their banks as regards the floating of timber, as well as the control of all forest produce in transit by land or water, is vested in the State Government which may make rules to regulate the transit of any forest produce.

facts.text: Section 37(2)(b) allows rules to prohibit import, export, collection or moving of forest produce without a pass.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section (2) provides Such rules may, among other matters, (a) (b) prohibit the import, export, collection, or moving of forest produce without a pass from an officer authorised to issue the same, or otherwise than in accordance with the conditions of such pass

facts.text: State filed affidavit asserting restrictions reasonable to prevent unauthorised felling and smuggling, night checking difficult.

anchor.surface_text: It was asserted in the affidavit filed on behalf of the State in reply to the petition that the restriction imposed by the rules on the freedom of citizens to transport timber, fire-wood, charcoal and bamboos is a reasonable restriction and in the public interest, i.e. to prevent unauthorised felling of trees and bamboos and smuggling them from the State forests.

facts.text: Smugglers find nights convenient to avoid detection.

anchor.surface_text: that persons who indulge in smuggling of timber find nights more convenient to avoid detection, and that smuggling of forest produce is a serious menace to preservation of forests in the State and safeguarding of the property of the State.

facts.text: Supreme Court held the two provisos restrictive not regulatory.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was, therefore, in our view, right in holding that the two provisos to r. 2 are not regulatory in character, but are restrictive.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld High Court on Art. 301 violation.

anchor.surface_text: The alternative ground on which the High Court has decided against the State Government must also be sustained. Article 301 provides Subject to the other provisions of this Part, trade, commerce and intercourse throughout the territory of India shall be free.

holdings.text: The power which the State Government may exercise under Section 37 is power to regulate transport of forest produce, and not the power to prohibit or restrict transport.

anchor.surface_text: The power which the State Government may exercise is however power to regulate transport of forest produce, and not the power to prohibit or restrict transport. Prima facie, H a rule which totally prohibits the movement of forest produce during the period between sun-set and sun-rise is prohibitory or restrictive of the right to transport forest produce.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.37(1) vests control to make rules to regulate transit; s.37(2)(b) allows prohibition without pass as regulatory; clauses j,l do not restrict transport itself; substance over form distinguishes regulation (promotes orderly transport) from restriction (obstructs).

holdings.text: The two provisos to r. 2 are not regulatory in character, but are restrictive, acting in excess of powers under s.37.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was, therefore, in our view, right in holding that the two provisos to r. 2 are not regulatory in character, but are restrictive. The alternative ground on which the High Court has decided against the State Government must also be sustained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds High Court; first proviso absolute ban sunset-sunrise, second qualified sunset-10pm; imposes prohibition/restriction on transport right unlike original permit rule; good public interest grounds (prevent smuggling) do not convert restriction to regulation.

holdings.text: The two provisos are restrictive of trade and commerce and derogate from the freedom declared by Art.301.

anchor.surface_text: The alternative ground on which the High Court has decided against the State Government must also be sustained. Article 301 provides Subject to the other provisions of this Part, trade, commerce and intercourse throughout the territory of India shall be free. The provisos are undoubtedly restrictive of trade and commerce

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.301 guarantees free trade subject to Part XIII; restrictive measures hit by it unless saved; provisos not regulatory (which facilitate) but hamper (citing Automobile case).

holdings.text: The two provisos are not saved by Art.305 as they are post-Constitution rules and not existing law.

anchor.surface_text: The plea that Art. 301 does not come to the aid of the respondent because of the reservation made in Art. 305 has, in our judgment, no substance. Article 305, insofar, as it is material, provides Nothing in articles 301 and 303 shall affect the provisions of any existing law

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.366(10) defines existing law as pre-Constitution; s.37 enabling provision existing but post-1950 rules exercising it are not; follows Kalyani Stores, distinguishes Kasi Prasad.

holdings.text: Article 304 has no application to the provisos.

anchor.surface_text: Article 304 which is an exception to Art. 301 has no application to this case, because that Article saves certain laws from the operation of Art. 301 if the law is passed by the Legislature of a State.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.304(b) saves state legislature laws imposing reasonable restrictions in public interest after enquiry; provisos are executive rules under delegated power (s.77 confirms force of law but not part of Act); no evidence of public interest enquiry.

holdings.text: By r. 2 framed under s.37(2)(b), requiring pass for transport, is clearly regulatory of the right to transport forest produce.

anchor.surface_text: By r. 2 which is framed in exercise of the power under s. 37  2   b , a person intending to transport forest produce must obtain a pass from an authorised officer. The rule so made is clearly regulatory ,of the right to transport forest produce.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Matches s.37(2)(b) prohibiting movement without pass; conditions promote orderly transit.

anchor.surface_text: The power which the State Government may exercise is however power to regulate transport of forest produce, and not the power to prohibit or restrict transport. Prima facie, H a rule which totally prohibits the movement of forest produce during the period between sun-set and sun-rise is prohibitory or restrictive of the right to transport forest produce.

The High Court was, therefore, in our view, right in holding that the two provisos to r. 2 are. number regulatory in character, but are restrictive. The alternative ground on which the High Court has decided against the State Government must also be sustained.
tions but regulatory provisions for without it, the necessary lines of companymunications,such as roads, water-ways and air-ways cannot effectively be

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was, therefore, in our view, right in holding that the two provisos to r. 2 are not regulatory in character, but are restrictive. The alternative ground on which the High Court has decided against the State Government must also be sustained.
s imposed on the right to transport forest produce by the two provisos incorporated in the rule in 1959 1960. By the first proviso the holder ,of a pa

edges.explanation: Holding states provisos not regulatory but restrictive, directly addressing issue

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was, therefore, in our view, right in holding that the two provisos to r. 2 are. number regulatory in character, but are restrictive. The alternative ground on which the High Court has decided against the State Government must also be sustained.

The alternative ground on which the High Court has decided against the State Government must also be sustained. Article 301 provides Subject to the other provisions of this Part, trade, commerce and intercourse throughout the territory of India shall be free. The provisos are undoubtedly restrictive of trade and commerce

The High Court was, therefore, in our view, right in holding that the two provisos to r. 2 are. number regulatory in character, but are restrictive. The alternative ground on which the High Court has decided against the State Government must also be sustained.

The plea that Art. 301 does not come to the aid of the respondent because of the reservation made in Art. 305 has, in our judgment, no substance. Article 305, insofar, as it is material, provides Nothing in articles 301 and 303 shall affect the provisions of any existing law

The High Court was, therefore, in our view, right in holding that the two provisos to r. 2 are. number regulatory in character, but are restrictive. The alternative ground on which the High Court has decided against the State Government must also be sustained.

Article 304 which is an exception to Art. 301 has no application to this case, because that Article saves certain laws from the operation of Art. 301 if the law is passed by the Legislature of a State.

The High Court was, therefore, in our view, right in holding that the two provisos to r. 2 are. number regulatory in character, but are restrictive. The alternative ground on which the High Court has decided against the State Government must also be sustained.
